alert.note: Alert for Christian; Greene; Lawrence; Stone; Webster; Wright (Missouri) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued March 24 at 2:20AM CDT until March 24 at 4:45AM CDT by NWS Springfield
info.description: The National Weather Service in Springfield has extended the * Flash Flood Warning for... Northern Christian County in southwestern Missouri... Southern Greene County in southwestern Missouri... Southern Lawrence County in southwestern Missouri... Northwestern Stone County in southwestern Missouri... Webster County in southwestern Missouri... Wright County in southwestern Missouri... * Until 445 AM CDT. * At 220 AM CDT, Local law enforcement reported thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 2 and 3 inches of rain have fallen. Flash flooding is already occurring. HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms. SOURCE...Law enforcement reported. IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas. * Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Springfield, Nixa, Ozark, Republic, Monett, Aurora, Marshfield, Battlefield, Strafford, Rogersville, Marionville, Clever, Seymour, Crane, Pierce City, Billings, Fordland, Verona, Hartville, Niangua, Diggins, Fremont Hills, Dawson, Duncan, Brookline, Hurley, Northview, Turners, Bassville, Linden, Galloway, Rader, Odin, Boaz, Grovespring, Manes and Graff. This includes the following highways... Interstate 44 between mile markers 64 and 106. This includes the following low water crossings... Beaver Creek at Crewes Ford Road, Wilson`s Creek at Old Limey Road, Little Crane Creek at Old Wire Road, Green Valley Creek at Holder RD, Whetstone Creek at Owens Road, Elk Creek at Highway Z and James River at Bell Ford Road. FLASH FLOOD...OBSERVED
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Many flood deaths occur in vehicles. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding.
